awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Collaborative Research: Towards Intelligent Multi-User Augmented Reality with Edge Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Augmented reality (AR), which overlays digital content with the real world around a user, has only recently become available to everyday users. AR applications are finding initial adoption in multiple areas including education, medicine, and gaming. Yet, the technology is currently in its infancy, limited in its ability to adapt to user preferences and environmental conditions, and offering restricted multi-user capabilities. Delivering adaptive multi-user AR experiences poses challenges to existing mobile systems and adaptation algorithms. From a mobile systems perspective, AR devices have strict energy and computing constraints and may experience network failures. Algorithmically, existing adaptation algorithms are often based on distributed machine learning, which is not designed to run on constrained AR devices and may not cope well with environment dynamics. This work will leverage edge computing as a solution for the mobile systems challenges, designing system architectures optimized to provide the similar but not identical user experiences required for multi-user AR. The work will also quantify the performance of existing distributed learning approaches under the constraints of multi-user AR, and will develop algorithms that optimize the resulting performance tradeoffs. The work will finally result in a dataset of AR-related inputs, outputs, and system and network resource utilization characteristics, which will be released publicly for the use of a wider community of researchers to validate their work on AR systems and algorithms. 

This project will enable AR capabilities not possible with existing stand-alone or cloud-supported AR, and will extend the scope of applications of machine learning in AR. The work will allow for the development of new AR applications for education, medicine, retail, and gaming that better engage users through delivering more personalized and dynamic user experiences. The developed solutions will be tested in education-specific settings at Duke Lemur Center, where AR will be used to educate visitors to the center about endangered animals and conservation efforts. The research will be integrated into course curricula at Duke and Carnegie Mellon and will be used as the basis for several undergraduate and graduate independent research projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Augmented reality (AR) is an exciting new technology that promises to fundamentally change how its users interact with their environments. Realizing this promise, however, is challenging: while mobile devices like headsets and smartphones offer the most convenient interfaces for users to interact with AR applications, they have limited computing resources to actually run these applications and adapt to the surrounding environment in real time. Such limitations are particularly acute for multi-user AR experiences, which may need to adapt in response to not just one but multiple users at once. These adaptations are generally realized with distributed machine learning algorithms, which can learn how to best adapt the AR experience based on past observations. Typical distributed machine learning algorithms, however, are not designed to run on resource-constrained mobile devices as needed for AR and may require prohibitive amounts of computing or communication resources.

This project developed new algorithms for distributed learning that are designed to meet the resource constraints and learning needs of multi-user AR applications. The two main challenges addressed were (i) AR devices move in and out of the learning system as users move around and enter and exit the AR experience; and (ii) multiple AR users sharing an experience often need to learn correlated, yet distinct, models. The project addresses these challenges in the context of federated learning algorithms, in which each AR user’s device iteratively trains a model on its local data. At periodic intervals, these models are aggregated to form a global model that takes into account data from all devices.

Users’ movements in and out of an AR experience can destabilize federated learning algorithms, since users who have exited the experience would not contribute to learning new model updates. Thus, this project developed novel model aggregation methods that correct for this unevenness. To address the problem of limited resources at AR user devices, the project developed methods to offload computations to less resource-constrained devices and selectively incorporate data into the learned models, which in experiments significantly reduced computing resource usage without much decrease in the learned model’s accuracy. 

To address the challenge of AR users’ requiring correlated but distinct models, the project first took a personalized learning approach, in which each device learned an individualized model that was nevertheless informed by data from other devices. We then used graphs to model interactions between users and developed methods to train graph-based models in a federated manner. These methods not only trained more accurate models than prior works, but also used significantly less communication and memory resources.

Finally, this project supported several education and outreach initiatives, as well as organizing of events to promote academic research in federated learning. These included co-organizing the first workshops on Cross-Domain Federated Learning (at the MLSys conference) and Distributed Machine Learning and Fog Networks (at the IEEE INFOCOM conference). The PI spoke at several events aimed to promote the participation of women in computer networking research, and she also served as the inaugural chair of the ACM SIGMETRICS Student Engagement Committee, to more generally promote student involvement in performance evaluation research.
